rawLines.text: I have the absolute pleasure and honor
of being here with uh with Secretary
Bergam to talk about to talk about his
new role in Secretary of the Interior,
energy, abundance, and all other things.
But maybe I want to start with your
personal story. The short version is
you're from North Dakota. You you um
launched your career as an entrepreneur
and investor. You built a company. You
sold it to Microsoft. you ran, you know,
a huge part of Microsoft for a long
time. And then you didn't stop there.
You you ran a venture firm. You invested
in companies like Atlassian when they
were really small, uh, and, you know,
helped them grow to IPO. You served on
the boards of multiple multi-billion
dollar companies. I mean, that's a lot.
And then one day you decided to run for
governor. So, tell us about what called
you to public life. What what made you,
you know, what made you make that switch
and make that journey? Well, thank
thanks Erin and uh thanks everybody for
being here and thanks Andre and Horowitz
for sponsoring this amazing conference.
So grateful for all of you here that if
you're here and you're part of this
conversation, you're an important part
of America and I just want to say thank
you to that because I'm sure a lot of
you are thinking the same thing that I
was thinking and answering your question
was uh having been an entrepreneur,
built companies, had success, you were
thinking, hey, how do I give back? Well,
then I started looking at the
philanthropic work like working with the
local rural high school that I had had
where I was had grown up that when I was
there and there's no computers or and
like how do we move that forward? Well,
then I started asking questions about
what does the state of North Dakota
spend on K12 as a state? And I found out
that our little state was spending a
billion dollars a year on on K12. And I
came home to Katherine one night and I
said, "Hey, uh maybe we should give our
time instead of giving money because
it's going to have a bigger impact." the
the levers of that. So the whole thing
was driven by impact and it's another
story what her reaction was when I said
that I can imagine. And so what are some
of the similarities and differences that
you found um as an executive and now
maybe as governor and now leading the
Department of the Interior? Well, I I
think that any of you that have ever had
any pull towards public service, uh I
would just recommend, you know, get into
an operating job. I I no interest really
in politics. I will never be a senator,
a congressman. Uh but we need people
that know how to actually run things and
can bring business principles and being
a governor uh and being a governor in a
state like North Dakota where you've got
enormous power to actually drive uh a
number of things. The land board, the
the land, minerals, the uh the there's
actually North Dakota is the only state
that has a state bank. You get to be
chairman of a bank when you're the when
you're the governor. Uh so there's all
these things where you can just bring
business principles about how do you you
know treat taxpayers like customers? How
do you focus on innovation uh over
regulation you know how do you cut red
tape to drive capital formation? How do
you make sure that talent is flowing
towards your state instead of away from
your state and that involves getting
involved in building you know smart
healthy communities. So it's just a
super fun cool job for anybody that
loves doing operating work and you can
really just you know avoid a lot of the
of the politics. And so then I you go
from being a governor to leading uh
interior uh which is a fantastic uh
again opportunity giant turnaround
65,000 people work in interior across 14
time zones and the span of what interior
controls I mean but the quick summary is
it's America's balance sheet there's you
know almost 500 million acres of surface
700 million acres of subsurface and 2.5
billion of offshore just to start with
uh not to mention all the national parks
the wildlife refugees, uh, you know, 574
federally recognized tribes that we've
got trust and responsibility to work
with the the all of the these things.
That's America's balance sheet. If if
Interior was a standalone company, it
would be the largest balance sheet in
the world, uh, bar none. I mean, you
know, Saudi Ramco, no one would come
close to it. But but the returns are
just horrible. I mean, the return I
mean, the amount of revenue coming off
of all of that for the for the American
people is uh, is sad. So when I say it's
a part of the turnaround, I mean the way
we balance the budget, the the way we
reduce the deficits, uh the way we drive
uh our American economy and the way we,
you know, do things like developing
energy resources to sell to our friends
and allies uh so that they don't have to
buy from our adversaries. A lot of that

super excited and uh and anybody here
that's like, "Hey, someday I got the
poll. I want to do, you know, government
a room full of entrepreneurs like this.
Jump into the operating jobs because
you'll make a huge difference. So, let's
get into your priorities now as
Secretary of the Interior. You know,
you've come out really in favor of
energy abundance. Um, but maybe can we
unpack that a little bit? What what do
you mean by that? Um, beyond just sort
of have more energy, what are the some
of the specific priorities you have in

roles plural because uh part of what uh
in the in in the discussion uh coming
into the this administration, uh there
was a lot of discussion and part of the
discussion was hey, we need Chris Wright
uh to lead Department of Energy, someone
I've known for 20 years. He's brilliant.
Uh he's he he was the right guy. He's
got a background in nuclear, geothermal,
and all the things that go on in energy.
Uh and it's really a partnership then
with Interior because he's got a bunch
of stuff. We've got all of the land and
the minerals. uh and critical minerals,
surface mining, all of the things in
interior. So in the discussion as the we
were forming the administration uh one
of the discussions we had that President

executive order was the national energy
dominance council and about twothirds of
the cabinet sits on that on that council
and he's asked me to chair it Chris
Wright to be the vice chair and our our
priorities are are pretty simple which
is we've got to make sure that we've got
abundance of energy to be able to drive
the priorities here at home which is in
in the top of the list is for AI. We do
not have enough electricity for AI. We
can go into that in more depth, but that
is, you know, that's like a number one.
That's why he he announced on day one,
President Trump, that we have a national
energy emergency. It wasn't necessarily
about price at the pump. It was we don't
have enough electricity and we're going
to lose the AI arms race with China. So,
that was that's one of our priorities.
The other one is that again on this
selling energy to our friends and
allies, the two the two proxy wars that
have been going on under the Biden
administration, you know, with Iran
funding 24 terror groups and with the uh
Russian invasion of Ukraine, uh both of
those conflicts were being funded by by
oil sales of those adversaries and we
were failing in our sanctions against
those two those two adversaries. And so
part of it on the the National Energy
Dominance Council includes Marco Rubio,
Scott Bessant, uh Howard Lutnik, uh Pam
Bonding, I mean all the people that we
need to make sure that we're ensuring
our interests abroad as well as here.
And then anybody that could block energy
development home. So we we need to get
our prosperity at home, peace abroad.
Those are kind of the highest level
order bits and energy is fundamental to
both of those missions. Smack smack in

on the you know the various different
sources we've talked a little bit about

across kind of nuclear solar
hydroelectric oil and gas you know how

well technology plays a key role in all

challenged and transformed by technology

unreliable energy because we were going

techrich just the traditional oil and

But in North Dakota, the Bacan, which

that's it's a 30foot layer of shale. And

they go down two miles, they turn a

last year as governor, 75% of the

a 50% increase in productive shale for
the same one drilling rig. What industry

kind of breakthroughs that are
happening. So I'm in a drill shack with

watching him do this. There's not a drop

There's no oil around. It's not like,
you know, Daniel Lewis and there will be

there's like black and white movies from
the 50. I mean, that's not happening.
There's like literally the clean one of
the cleanest industries. And I said,
"How, you know, how do you stay in? How
do you stay in a 30foot strip for that
for two miles?" And he said, "Sir, if
your house was 2 miles down underground
and two miles over, I could drill the
lock out on the front door." Oh my god.
you know, so it's like and that was this
is several years ago. I mean, the
technology's gotten even better. So, the
technology is affecting all of these
geothermal, nuclear. There's a whole

u wind every day because wind doesn't

um you're seeing the cloud providers,

we have to stop creating artificial dam

we've got a bunch of policy changes and
